snippet: Investors have pulled back in May in recent years, but there are forces working against a repeat.
abstract: Paul J Lim Fundamentally column contends investors have pulled back in May in recent years, but says there are forces working against a repeat; points out that although oil prices are up moderately in 2012, prices for many other commodities are not; notes central banks around the world have been lowering interest rates to spark growth; cites other factors for market optimism. (M)
lead_paragraph: IT'S understandable if the month of May fills investors with trepidation. After all, almost a year ago, equities entered a near-bear market that pushed stocks lower by more than 19 percent. That came after a very promising start to the year, a pattern that also occurred in 2010. And this year through April, the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index returned nearly 12 percent.

headline.main: A Pullback in May? Maybe Not This Time
